widgets_values: WHEN CHANGING WHICH MODEL LOADER PREFERRED, MODEL CONNECTS AT THIS POINT

The video begins with a perfectly static orthographic view of the dense city block, matching the provided input image. The perspective is strictly telecentric; vertical lines of the skyscrapers do not converge toward a vanishing point, giving the scene a distinct, map-like isometric appearance. The camera initiates a slow, unwavering diagonal drift toward the top-right of the frame, moving at a constant velocity of approximately 15 virtual meters per second. The lighting is established as mid-morning, with the sun positioned at a 45-degree angle, casting hard, defining shadows that stretch diagonally across the streets.

As the camera drifts, the physics of light interacting with the building materials is rendered with ray-traced precision. The sun strikes the eastern facades of the high-rises, revealing high-frequency textures: the roughness of weathered concrete, the matte finish of red brick, and the glossy sheen of aluminum composite panels. Conversely, the western faces are plunged into deep, cool-toned ambient occlusion shadows, maintaining detail but lacking direct specular highlights. On the flat rooftops, HVAC units and ventilation ducts appear as geometric primitives; the metallic surfaces of the ducts catch the sunlight, creating bright, overexposed specular hot spots that do not bloom but remain sharp, consistent with a high-aperture lens. There is no lens distortion or chromatic aberration at the edges; the image remains clinically sharp from corner to corner.

blurry, out of focus, overexposed, underexposed, low contrast, washed out colors, excessive noise, grainy texture, poor lighting, flickering, motion blur, distorted proportions, unnatural skin tones, deformed facial features, asymmetrical face, missing facial features, extra limbs, disfigured hands, wrong hand count, artifacts around text, unreadable text on shirt or hat, incorrect lettering on cap (PNTR), incorrect t-shirt slogan (JUST DO IT), missing microphone, misplaced microphone, inconsistent perspective, camera shake, incorrect depth of field, background too sharp, background clutter, distracting reflections, harsh shadows, inconsistent lighting direction, color banding, cartoonish rendering, 3D CGI look, unrealistic materials, uncanny valley effect, incorrect ethnicity, wrong gender, exaggerated expressions, smiling, laughing, exaggerated sadness, wrong gaze direction, eyes looking at camera, mismatched lip sync, silent or muted audio, distorted voice, robotic voice, echo, background noise, off-sync audio, missing sniff sounds, incorrect dialogue, added dialogue, repetitive speech, jittery movement, awkward pauses, incorrect timing, unnatural transitions, inconsistent framing, tilted camera, missing door or shelves, missing shallow depth of field, flat lighting, inconsistent tone, cinematic oversaturation, stylized filters, or AI artifacts.

The camera maintains a steady eye-level tracking shot, keeping the man centered as he continues his walk. The residential scenery immediately begins to transition; the picket fences and houses give way to the textured brick facades of a commercial district. The natural lighting deepens slightly, shifting from bright amber to a softer dusk purple, though the warm rim light on the man remains consistent. He walks with a fluid, unbreaking gait, passing by darkened shop windows and streetlamps that have just flickered to life. The focus remains sharp on him while the storefrontsa hardware store, a barber shopblur past in the periphery, establishing the shift from a quiet neighborhood to a main street environment without any interruption to the camera's movement.

Continuing the seamless diagonal drift, the camera reveals a major arterial intersection sliding into the frame from the bottom-left. The continuity of the orthographic projection remains absolute; new buildings enter the frame maintaining perfectly parallel vertical edges relative to the previous structures. Attention shifts to the street level, deeply recessed between the "canyons" of the buildings. Traffic moves in a rhythmic, mechanical simulation.

Cars appear as small, distinct rectangles with softened corners. The physics of their movement is stop-and-go; a line of yellow taxis accelerates simultaneously when a traffic light (visible only by its cast light on the asphalt) turns green. The vehicles exhibit subtle suspension compression as they brake, dipping their front ends imperceptibly. The asphalt texture below them is visible as a coarse, grey grain, interrupted by white thermoplastic lane markings that reflect light with a higher intensity than the road surface. Windshields of the moving cars act as dynamic mirrors; as they travel through the alternating patches of shadow and sunlight cast by the buildings, the glass flares with sudden, transient reflections of the sky, creating a flickering "glint" effect that traverses the traffic line. Pedestrians are visible as tiny, distinct specks on the sidewalks, their shadows elongating and shortening as they walk past the gaps in the architecture.

The camera drift persists without deviation in speed or trajectory. The dense grid of concrete gives way slightly as an urban park enters the field of view. The visual phenomenology shifts from rigid geometry to organic chaos, though still constrained by the flat, orthographic perspective. The trees in the park appear as textured, distinct circles of varying shades of green.

The physics of wind is introduced here. The tree canopies oscillate gently, creating a shimmering effect as the leaves turn and catch the sunlight at different angles. This motion is not uniform; it ripples across the clusters of foliage like a fluid wave, indicating a breeze moving West to East. Beneath the trees, the grass texture creates a noise pattern that contrasts with the smooth, uniform grey of the surrounding sidewalks. A small, man-made pond within the park reflects the sky as a flat, solid blue plane, interrupted only by the dark, wavering reflections of the surrounding high-rises. The water surface shows no chop, only a slow, viscous undulation that distorts the straight lines of the reflected building edges into sine waves. The shadows cast by the trees onto the grass are soft-edged and diffuse, contrasting with the razor-sharp shadows cast by the buildings in the previous segments.

In the final ten seconds, the camera continues its steady drift, now passing over a district of mixed-use buildings with active rooftop amenities. The camera maintains the "God's eye" isometric view. A large cloud shadow, previously unseen, begins to sweep across the landscape from the left side of the frame, moving faster than the camera's drift.

As the shadow boundary crosses the scene, the exposure adjusts dynamically. The bright, high-contrast colors of the sunlit rooftopsturquoise swimming pools and terracotta tilesare momentarily muted into cooler, desaturated tones. The water in a rooftop pool shows caustic refraction patterns on its floor, which vanish instantly as the cloud shadow passes over, leaving the water a uniform dark teal. The shadow creates a moving gradient across the glass facades of the buildings, eliminating the Fresnel reflections on the windows for a few seconds before the light returns. On the very edge of the frame, steam rises from a cooling tower. The steam particle physics are rendered as volumetric puffs that dissipate rapidly into the air, casting faint, translucent shadows on the roof tar below. The video ends with the camera still drifting, implying an infinite, sprawling city grid that extends forever beyond the cropped view, with the lighting returning to full brightness as the cloud passes.

inputs.text: A medium close-up shot features a Caucasian man with a closely shaven head and face, wearing a black baseball cap with "PNTR" in white letters on the front, and a dark grey t-shirt with "JUST DO IT" visible across his chest. A small black microphone is clipped to his shirt collar. He is positioned slightly to the left of the frame, looking intently downwards and to his right, his eyes focused off-camera. His facial expression is one of deep concentration, with his brow slightly furrowed. As he looks down, a quick sniff sound is heard, and then he speaks with a deep male voice and a slightly frustrated tone, saying, "I think it's so bad." The camera remains static throughout, maintaining a shallow depth of field, which keeps the man in sharp focus while the background is softly blurred, revealing a light-colored wall with white wooden shelving or trim, and a partially open white wooden door on the right. After a brief pause, another short, audible sniff is heard. The man then continues to speak, his voice maintaining the same quality, as he states, "So bad. So bad." He elaborates further, emphasizing his point with a final statement, "This got to be, it's got to be the worst tool I've ever seen."
